Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 02:31PM Angel10 wrote: Here it is cut and pasted:  Your life after cancer is better than the one before A year and a half after breast cancer, life is good for TODAY's Hoda Kotb I was devastated.  I was also determined to beat it, and so was the incredible support system around me. With my sister Hala, my mom Sami, my brother Adel and countless friends behind me (couldn't have done it without them!), I underwent a mastectomy and reconstructive surgery in March 2007.  And a funny thing happened as my body started to heal - my mind did as well.  The world just suddenly snapped into focus.  Everything that was important became totally clear, and so did the negative parts of my life that I needed to let go of if I wanted to follow my new mantra - go forward...Forward. Forward. Forward. Staring down the scariest thing that could have happened to me gave me the strength to take on new challenges I didn't have the courage to tackle past.  When I got back to work, one of the first things I did was walk into my bosses' offices - NBC News president Steve Capus and NBC Universal president and CEO Jeff Zucker - to tell them I wanted to be  TODAY's fourth-hour co-host.  Before cancer, I don't think I had the confidence to fight for the position, but  now here I am now, living my dream job with Kathie Lee every morning.  It's funny when I think how I owe my job, in part, to cancer. Click for related content One of the opportunities I've had in my new role on TODAY is the ability to share my journey with the audience.  As a journalist, taking my personal life public was a tough thing to do, but the response I've gotten has made me so glad I found the courage to open up.  More often than you would think, people come up to me on the streets of New York and, without a word, just give me a hug.  Nine times out of 10, that person has had breast cancer or knows someone who has.  My position also let's me bring awareness to this horrible disease, and attention on the desperate need for a cure.  It blows my mind that in 2008 our answer to breast cancer is still lobbing off body parts and essentially setting off a bomb on a person's insides.  It's my hope we'll find a cure in my lifetime, and bringing you stories like Dr. Susan Love's Army of Women, as well as the stories we'll highlight throughout the month of October, is a step in the right direction. It would be wrong to paint everything about breast cancer in a positive light.  There are times wearing or new dress or at the beach in a bathing suit and I look down and I think, "That's not me.  I'm not whole."  Rationally I know that I am not my body, but I still struggle with those physical insecurities.  And perhaps that hardest part of this process is knowing that cancer has robbed me of the chance to be a biological mother.  The medication I take every day to kill the stray cancer cell that may be swimming in my blood stream essentially shuts down my reproductive system.  That is really tough. Still, the most surprising side effects of cancer is that it has given me more courage than I ever thought possible.   My life after cancer is more courageous and more honest and fuller than my life before. So to the woman with cancer who is in her bed right now and feeling so sick she doesn't want to even think about getting out of bed, I know how you're feeling.   And take it from me, I know going forward it's going to bet getter.  God gave me a second chance, and yours is about to start.  Welcome to the sisterhood of breast cancer survivors.  There's not a stronger, prouder or more determined group of women out there
Posts.Title: Uplifting Article Pure LRM216

Posts.Title: Hate to ask but need a couple prayers abbyglp pitanga

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 08:23PM Angel10 wrote: Hi Christine...so sorry to hear of all of this.  My first surgeon recommended lumpectomy with rad too, but I learned that if I did that I could not get implants in that breast if the cancer returned, so I opted to go with a bilateral mx with immediate reconstruction with TE.  I will admit that the reconstruction process is more difficult than I realized, and I do miss feeling my own breast tissue...but I really wanted the cancer out and minimize recurrance in the other breast.  Studies seem to show that what I did does NOT extend my life expectancy...but I did not want 2 different sized breasts w/o opportunity to do implants if the cancer came back....so I understand what you are saying.  Again, reconstruction has not been a picnic for me, but I know of others who felt it was no big deal....so there is no right or wrong answer here.  Ultimately yo umust weigh all the pros and cons and come to some acceptance of what you can live with. Sending you hugs and prayers, Angel
Posts.Title: Anyone Had Lumpect w/out Rads Afterwards? stateofgrace33 stateofgrace33

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2009 06:32PM Angel10 wrote: Sunshine....I did not have the axillary dissection this way...I did have 15 nodes taken during my BMX, (I had obvious lymphatic invasion even though the sentinel nodes showed negative) but I was fortunate to not have anything show up in the remaining nodes.  My sister on the other hand had a prophylactic BMX but when they checked her nodes...there were some positive ones!  So she too went back for for the axillary dissection as you are doing...I can't recall the recovery time, but I don't think she spent more than a day in the hospital. Just wanted you to know I saw your post and I am sorry this happened. Good news is that the cancer cells were microscopic and not overt.  I hope you have an easy time with this...and I am sure you will get some good info as to what to expect real soon. Good luck and God Bless! Angel
Posts.Title: Separate surgery--nodes removed Sunshine1958 Kayleigh3483

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 04:51PM Angel10 wrote: Hi gfrey! Coolbreeze and I are similar...I had invasive ductal, invasive tubulolobular (that's a mouthful!) DCIS, LCIS...grade 3.  I did have vascular invasion but no nodal involvement.  At first my onc wanted to do chemo but the Oncotype came back as 18 so he let me decide, and I said NO to chemo!  I has a BMX which was my way of saying NO to rads, as I knew my cancer was not up against the chest wall.  I am doing the tamoxifen....but may try going off it after the first of the year for a month because I am still feeling so tired and my BMX was in April...I would just like to see how I would feel w/o it.  My Oncotype score suggested an 18% reoccurrance rate w/o tamoxifen, 11% with it on board, so I am trying it. Good luck to all of us! God Bless!

Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 10:32PM Angel10 wrote: Hi Ladies!  Hope everyone isd having a great day! Moomysta, I had an excisional biopsy about 5 years ago, which was benign. I think I went to work the following day.  It was a bit sore, but not bad.  Regular bra...but I guess that would depend where in the breast the biopsy is being done with regards to how comfortable a bra would feel. Mine was firly centralized, not close to a bra line.  They put you under, so you will most likely get fasting guidelines for after midnight the night before...but you will get that info. And they do want someone to assist you home. I walked home with my husband...I think I did some window shopping, too! (I live in NYC!) An "exchange" surgery is part of the reconstruction process. I had a BMX (bilateral mastectomy) in April. During that same surgery they implanted "temporary"implants called "tissue expanders" (TE) which does exactly as it says.....slowly expands the remaining tissue to accept the permanent implants several months later.  The TE's are a pain....they are slowly filled week after week by a plastic surgeon (PS) until they get to a reasonable size for your body frame. Then after several weeks of settling, you go back in to remove the temporary and put in the permanent implants.  Everyone says that surgery is a real relief from what you experience with the TE's, which, did I mention, are a real pain...and are a much better shape. So I am actually looking forward to this next surgery!  :)  They scheduled the OR for 3 hours first thing Monday 7:30 AM, but I think that is more than enough time for what he is going to do. I will be home Monday afternoon. I hope you never need to go down this route, but if you do, there is plenty of info on these boards that offer alot of good info and support! I will be sure to drop in after the surgery...probably Tuesday to let you know.  Mommysta, good luck with your consultation. Come back here if you have any questions or thoughts afterwards!  And write them down Ladies...have a fabulous weekend! God Bless! Angel
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2009 02:28PM Angel10 wrote: Hi there...I am still tired and a bit sore...not that bad though...thanks for asking! The wire is there so that the doctor knows exactly where to take the tissue from. It will come out right after they do the excision. God Bless! Angel
Posts.Title: Pleomorphic Calcifications mommyalways Isellrejer

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 01:03PM Angel10 wrote: Hi Mommysta....hope you can keep it all together these next couple of days.... Regarding your MRI report, they should give that to you when you pick it up the images.  They cannot legally withhold your records...they are yours after all!  I can't imagine that some one has not read your MRI yet, but sometimes transcribing them is the hold up.  I can't really speak to how long after you will hear results on the biopsy.  That is pretty specific to the facility. How long I think women should wait is a whole other story!;) If I can recall mine from 2004 I think I had my excision on a Tuesday morning and did not hear until Friday. I do remember being annoyed because I felt they should have called me as soon as they had them, which was not the case.  When I had not heard by Friday, I called and got them then. The only questions I think I would ask is what you are asking here...how long before I get the results and why isn't the other breast being worked up?  I will say that calcifications in of themselves is not necessarily an abnormality. It depends upon how they look, i.e. how the cluster is formed, whether or not they are layered (remember your first report?) and some other considerations that are difficult to interpret!  Perhaps they feel the ones on the right don't look abnormal....but I would ask anyway! I will say that a sister of mine developed a very good relationship with her BS over time...she had several lumpectomies. At one point on the way going into the OR she told him she felt that there was something going on in the other breast, and pointed out where.  He went ahead and biopsied that one at the same time as he had her under for the other.  Good thing, as she had cancer on both sides.  That is not to worry you at all.  Her situation was totally different.....but in the end you need to trust that you know your body and yet are not worrying about something that is not worth worrying about, and as importantly, you need to trust your BS and be able to communicate with him/her...effectively and openly. You need to trust their decisions.  If not find another. I hope that helps... I continue to mend...3 nights in a row of milk of magnesia...so I was up all last night! Wearing this surgical bra 24/7 is a real pain, but I don't want to mess with the results, so I will do what I am supposed to do. I have another visit this Thursday with my PS. I will wait a couple of months and decide how I want to deal with nipple reconstruction. I have time for that. One final thing...I promise not to nag....smoking does not help the vascular healing process, or scars for that matter.  My husband smoked for years...tried quitting several times. Finally his doc put him on Wellbutrin and that finally did the trick. It is said to be the worst habit to kick...and probably not something that you need to think about right now...but you need to get at it. It is nuts to deal with the possibility of breast cance which we can't help, yet at the same time creating such a high risk for lung cancer.  We need to try and control what we can....OK, ok....enough said! I promised I would not nag! God Bless!

Posts.Title: Taking NSAIDs after surgery? MI_Runner roseg

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 10:48AM Angel10 wrote: Becky, So sorry you are dealing with this....it is interesting since you both work in the same department.  My first inclination was to ask how does your husband feel about you saying something?  Initially since it is "his" situation, he should be calling the shots or saying something...not you.  But perhaps there are dynamics going on here that are not easily seen by the both of you as you are both in it.  Is there anyone else in your department or work place that could give you a perspective "once removed"?  If you could contain yourself and approach the reluctant teacher in a reasonable manner I would say try that.  But "venting" just to get it off your chest (no pun intended) may not make the rest of the work year tolerable.  Stay focused...what do you want? What will get you there? A reasonable appeal? Another schedule/plan? Asking the other teacher what would work for them in light of your circumstances? I would just caution against venting for the sake of venting since you are both still working there. See if there is still a way to get what you want....any other "win, win" situation that might not be seen at first blush. Wish I had a more direct answer for you... Good luck and God Bless! Angel
Posts.Title: Disappointment in Coworkers - how to move past this rkt rkt

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 10:54PM Angel10 wrote: Hello all...if I can share my family's story, my father died of stomach cancer before we knew it was genetic.  When the CDH1 gene was discovered and we were tested, after noting several cousins dying of gastric cancer in their 40-50's it was also noted that there is a high occurrance of breast cancer with women with this mutation.  8 of 11 siblings have tested positve for this gene (I did not).  Of the 8, 3 are male, 5 female.  2 brothers and 3 sisters has had the total gastrectomies.  It has been life altering and I would strongly suggest nutritional and supportive counseling prior to going this route.  3 of the 5 had beginnings of gastric cancer so the decision was appropriate, but I strongly recommend support before, during and after surgery.  2 of the 4  positive sisters had already experienced breast cancer in one or both breasts prior to the genetic knowledge.   The other 2 sisters who had the TG (total gastrectomy) also decided to have prophylactic bilateral mastectomies. Both had negative mammo's; neg U/S and neg MRI's but decided to go ahead anyway.  Both ended up having BC after all.  I was one of the few that "dodged the bullet" yet 2 months ago I was dx with both ductal and lobular carcinoma....go figure. I chose a BM because I am a bit done with cancer if you can appreciate what the last 3 years have been like around my family, and as it turned out I truly feel like I made the right decision based upon my pathology report ...although I hate my TE's!!  Patience is the virtue that I still in need of developing, I know this too shall pass. There is a wonderful website called HDGC@yahoo.com for support around this issue.  Although rare, the more we learn the more testing is being done, and more people are being found to have this genetic issue.  We are at the tip of the iceberg when it comes to genetic mutations....and right now although Total Gastrectomies and prophylactic BM seem draconian....it is the best we have to save our lives, extend time with family and loved ones and fight for more research and a cure. There is info out there, try to get informed as much as possible...good luck to you and God Bless!  Angel10
Posts.Title: E-cadherin gene mutations Joanie jhoncena1941

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 03:46PM Angel10 wrote: Hi there freudgirl...so sorry to see you are going through this. Was just checking another thread on genetic issues...I am one of 5 sisters with BC and we are BRCA neg, but there is another genetic mutation with stomach and breast that my sisters have...but I don't. Waiting is the worst part of this....and no consolation I am sure, but if it were cancer 2 days more would probably not make any difference. Now an infection is something you want to treat quickly and hopefully that will be what you are dealing with. Not sure what kind of relationship yo uhave with your internist, but if this turns out benign perhpas your internist could see you quicker than the onc next time?  Regardless, if you ever hit a wall and just need to see someone...go to the ER at the hospital your onc works at! Hang in...best of luck and let me know how you do. God Bless! Angel
Posts.Title: Significant Fam History and new problems freudgirl38 Angel10

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 04:14PM Angel10 wrote: Mommysta, No I can't say I was not feeling well prior to my dx. Picture of health. I had my mammo and u/s on a Tuesday. My radiologist did not like what she saw so she biopsied it right there and then under ultrasound guidance. I got my path report from the biopsy that Thursday afternoon.  So I did not have to wait long. But from what I have read from this site, that varies from practice to practice, so no standards or norms. I would EXPECT that within the week they should let you know the results....hopefully sooner. It is an anxious time. I had a surgical breast biopsy 5 years ago and was not concerned about that one AT ALL.  This time, I was not so sure but was determined not to worry too much until I knew...The way I figured it, if it was cancer I would have plenty of time to worry...if not, I was wasting time and was worrying my family for no reason, so I  tried not to obsess. It is a difficult time...hang in there. My dx was this past February. I had a bilat mx in April and have TE's which will hopefully be exchanged in 2 weeks.  It has been a roller coaster ride, but I focus on the fact that I no longer have breast cancer. Take a deep breath....one day and one test at a time. You have a tremendous support network here at this site, and hopefully with your family and friends. Keep us posted. God Bless, Angel

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 03:05AM Angel10 wrote: mommysta...it is exactly what it sounds like.   The cells are that line the milk ducts are irregular.  Without further info you can't read into it much more than that.  I am afraid you are still in the waiting game...It does not mean that it is cancerous, but having it increases your chance for cancer, so they want to go in and take more tissue out for a better look and find out what is going on. I was hoping to hear "all clear" but it looks like they will want to be thorough and look closer.  Hang in there my dear....one step at a time.  Please keep us posted and let us know when your biopsy is scheduled. Posts.Content: Angel10 wrote: Ladies... Just a quick FYI...I have listened in on several conferences hosted by Living Beyond Breast Cancer (http://www.lbbc.org/) They have a conference call tomorrow evening that all can register for on Follow up Testing 101.  It may be old info for many, but since these things seem to change from day to day, thought I would share.  I am cutting and pasting info. By pre-registering they will email info to you and the presentation handouts. God Bless! Follow-Up Testing 101 - New Evening Time! Our November teleconference will focus on the National Cancer Institute's guidelines for follow-up testing and why follow-up care may vary from doctor to doctor Speaker: Nancy U. Lin, MD Register for this free teleconference. Join Living Beyond Breast Cancer for our next free teleconference, Follow-Up Testing 101, at the new time from 7:00 p.m. to 8:15 p.m. Eastern Standard Time (EST) on Wednesday, November 18. Nancy U. Lin, MD, of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, will give you practical information about follow-up testing, including: The National Cancer Institute's guidelines for follow-up testing Why follow-up care may vary from doctor to doctor The differences in follow-up care between early-stage and advanced breast cancer The importance of a long-term survivorship plan How to communicate post-treatment concerns with your doctor About Our Speaker Dr. Lin is a medical oncologist at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute specializing in the care of women with breast cancer. Her research focuses on developing new therapies for women with brain metastases and women with HER2 positive breast cancer. Dr. Lin is an active member of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) and a recipient of an ASCO Foundation Young Investigator Award and Career Development Award. About the Program Our speaker will give a brief presentation, followed by a question-and-answer period. To participate, you need only a telephone or computer (listen-only) with Real Network Player or Windows Media Player. Social workers may be eligible to receive continuing education credits; see our registration form for more details. New Features for Online Participants A slideshow presentation will be available online during the program. You will also have the opportunity to submit questions for the question-and-answer session online Angel Dx 2/6/2009, ILC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/15 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Free Teleconference on Follow Up Testing after Breast Cancer DX Angel10 Angel10

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 10:19PM Angel10 wrote: Hi Debbie!  So sorry you are here with these worries.....you daughter is really young to be going through this.  19 is NOT a common age for breast cancer, but it is not impossible either, so it is always good to be vigilant particularly if something shows up on an ultrasound. I just want to advise you that should your daughter need to have a biopsy, please get a second opinion first....and make sure it is a breast surgeon that does it. If there is one thing for sure in my humble opinion is that breast cancer diagnosis, treatment and procedures, is always better done in the hands of those doctors that deal with this all the time, not just as a part of their practice. You will find tremendous information and support on this website, so you have come to the right place, but please, and I know that this is practically impossible to do, but please don't get crazy about this.  You really don't know what is going on, and 80% of what is looked out with breasts turn out to be harmless, benign or as we like to say here B9!  If there is something to be concerned about, you will have plenty of time to be concerned.  If there is nothing, then you will have wasted precious emotions and well being by worrying about  something that was not worth worrying about.  Either way, try to be the strong support your daughter will look up to either way. Give her a hug, tell her it is probably nothing but that you will get the best possible doctors to check it out, and in the mean time take it one step at a time. God bless you...and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2010 10:40AM Angel10 wrote: WLL, I pulled this off of the ACS site under tumor markers: CA-15-3 CA 15-3 is mainly used to watch patients with breast cancer. Elevated blood levels are found in less than 10% of patients with early disease and in about 70% of patients with advanced disease. Levels usually drop if treatment is working, but they may go up in the first few weeks after treatment is started. This rise is caused when dying cancer cells spill their contents into the bloodstream. The normal level is usually less than 30 U/mL (units/milliliter), depending on the lab. But levels as high as 100 U/mL can sometimes be seen in women who do not have cancer. Levels of this marker can also be higher in other cancers, like lung and ovarian, and in some non-cancerous conditions, like benign breast conditions and hepatitis. CA 27.29 CA 27.29 is another marker that can be used to follow patients with breast cancer during or after treatment. This test measures the same marker as the CA 15-3 test, but in a different way. Although it is a newer test than CA 15-3, it is not any better in detecting either early or advanced disease. It may be less likely to be positive in people without cancer. The normal level is usually less than 40 U/mL (units/milliliter), depending on the testing lab. This marker can also be elevated in other cancers and in some non-cancerous conditions, and it is not elevated in all patients with breast. The page can be found at http://www.cancer.org/docroot/PED/content/PED_2_3X_Tumor_Markers.asp?sitearea=PED Oncotype score is different, so you need to be sure of exactly what is being defined. I have heard that markers are not really useful individually, but should be taken under consideration with other info, test results.  Thay can be helpful, or misleading....  Good luck and God Bless!

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 02:07PM Angel10 wrote: Hi Ladies... Just a quick FYI...I have listened in on several conferences hosted by Living Beyond Breast Cancer (http://www.lbbc.org/) They have a conference call tomorrow evening that all can register for on Follow up Testing 101.  It may be old info for many, but since these things seem to change from day to day, thought I would share.  I am cutting and pasting info. By pre-registering they will email info to you and the presentation handouts. God Bless! Follow-Up Testing 101 - New Evening Time! Our November teleconference will focus on the National Cancer Institute's guidelines for follow-up testing and why follow-up care may vary from doctor to doctor Speaker: Nancy U. Lin, MD  Register for this free teleconference. Join Living Beyond Breast Cancer for our next free teleconference, Follow-Up Testing 101, at the new time from 7:00 p.m. to 8:15 p.m. Eastern Standard Time (EST) on Wednesday, November 18. Nancy U. Lin, MD, of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, will give you practical information about follow-up testing, including: About Our Speaker Dr. Lin is a medical oncologist at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute specializing in the care of women with breast cancer. Her research focuses on developing new therapies for women with brain metastases and women with HER2 positive breast cancer. Dr. Lin is an active member of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) and a recipient of an ASCO Foundation Young Investigator Award and Career Development Award. About the Program Our speaker will give a brief presentation, followed by a question-and-answer period. To participate, you need only a telephone or computer (listen-only) with Real Network Player or Windows Media Player. Social workers may be eligible to receive continuing education credits; see our registration form for more details. New Features for Online Participants A slideshow presentation will be available online during the program. You will also have the opportunity to submit questions for the question-and-answer session online

Posts.Title: Significant Fam History and new problems freudgirl38 Angel10

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 08:52PM Angel10 wrote: Carol, I think it will depend on your body, how much you will be filled and your PS philosophy. My PS told me most expansions should try to be completed in 8-10 weeks from mastectomy due to the fact that he believes that is when the skin is most opt to stretch easily. My TE placement was done at the same time as my bilat mx.  I waited 10 days for my first fill. When the TE's were placed they already had 50 cc's in them.  I did 3 fills of 150 cc's each, 1 per week for the next 3 weeks (my TE's are 600 CC large). To be honest, I thought I was going too fast! That last 150 cc fill was a doozy!  I ended up with a cellulitis infection, that I do not think was attributed to the fill rates, but nonetheless, I was hospitalized for 6 days and it slowed the whole process down. No complaints from me!   When I was released from the hospital I was put on long term antibiotics to be assured I was clear of any infection. Within 3 weeks I developed liver toxicity from the antibiotics and ended back in for another 6 day stay!  Before I was released I was at 500 cc's. I asked for a 50 cc fill in the hospital, was released and went back to the PS office 10 days later for a final 50 cc.  I am now at 600, my PS would have preferred 650 but I said "uncle"! I am done! Soooo...I started the last week of April and will have my exchange August 17th...with 2 unplanned hospitalizations.  No set procedures as you can see from the various responses. Hoep for the best, expect the unexpected and ask your PS what they think!  Let them walk you through what their process is...timing, fill rates etc.  I also think it is a good thing to show your PS that you are interested and knowledgeable about the process. I learned alot here....much more than I did from my own docs....so keep asking! Good Luck and God Bless! Angel
Posts.Title: time between mx & tissue expanders put in cpu386 Kathy16

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2009 01:09AM Angel10 wrote: Barbara, I knew something was wrong because my breasts were turning red, and I could feel the heat coming off of them.  I called my PS and he sent Keflex which improved the situation for a day or two, but it came back. I went to see him and he said, "into the hospital you go!".  I did not have a fever, nor increased WBC, and it did not culture anything, either, but there was no denying the redness and heat. I did have an elevated sedimentation rate, and that sealed the deal.  I needed 6 days of Vancomycin IV BID to clear it up.  Marybee, I was a 38DD before  my double MX and everyone seems to think I want to go there again....no thank you!  I am looking forward to being much smaller...it is an interesting phenomena in this culture when it thinks bigger is better...YUCK!  God Bless! Angel
